sources.title: The Ten Commandments (1923) | Colorized Public Domain Epic Silent Film Directed by Cecil B. DeMille
sources.description:
The Ten Commandments (1923) is an American silent epic directed by Cecil B. DeMille and produced by Paramount Pictures. Unlike the better-known 1956 remake, this earlier version was one of the most ambitious silent-era productions, blending biblical spectacle with a modern morality tale. This restored and colorized edition revives the grandeur of DeMille‚Äôs original vision, making it accessible for contemporary audiences across the United States, Europe, and worldwide. With its monumental sets, large-scale crowd sequences, and groundbreaking effects for its time, the film remains a cornerstone of early Hollywood spectacle.

Plot Summary:
The film is structured in two parts.

The first half dramatizes the biblical story of the Exodus. Moses (Theodore Roberts) receives the Ten Commandments from God on Mount Sinai and delivers them to the Israelites. The narrative focuses on the confrontation with Pharaoh, the dramatic plagues, and the parting of the Red Sea ‚Äî staged with elaborate special effects that stunned 1920s audiences. This portion highlights DeMille‚Äôs eye for grandeur and his pioneering use of large sets and visual innovation in silent cinema.

The second half shifts to a modern setting of the 1920s, where two brothers, John and Dan McTavish (Richard Dix and Rod La Rocque), live under the shadow of the Commandments. John is a devout believer who respects moral law, while Dan is a skeptic who dismisses religion and pursues wealth and pleasure at any cost. Dan‚Äôs disregard leads him into corruption, adultery, and crime, culminating in tragedy that serves as a stark warning against violating God‚Äôs laws. This dual structure makes the 1923 film unique ‚Äî both a biblical epic and a contemporary morality drama.

Film Significance:
The Ten Commandments (1923) was one of the first major Hollywood epics, setting a standard for biblical films and large-scale productions. Its monumental sets, some built on the California desert, became legendary ‚Äî with remnants buried in the sand at Guadalupe, California, where archaeologists later uncovered pieces of DeMille‚Äôs ‚Äúlost city.‚Äù While overshadowed today by the 1956 remake, the silent original deserves recognition for its innovation, ambition, and cultural influence. It captures both DeMille‚Äôs talent for spectacle and his belief in cinema as a tool for moral instruction. For silent film enthusiasts and students of cinema history, it is a milestone in early Hollywood storytelling.

metadata.Plot: The first part tells the story of Moses leading the Jews from Egypt to the Promised Land, his receipt of the tablets and the worship of the golden calf. The second part shows the efficacy of the commandments in modern life through a story set in San Francisco. Two brothers, rivals for the love of Mary, also come into conflict when John discovers Dan used shoddy materials to construct a cathedral.
